text: I agree that there's a bit of an issue comparing something that is to the nearest microsecond with something to the nearest millisecond. However, based on any sane rounding method, the fact remains that according to your clock in the first example you received the message before Betfair timestamped it. This might be expected infrequently but probably not to the extent that your example suggests. I suspect your system clock is not synchronised with an appropriate source. I wonder if this might explain the original observation

elements.text: I agree that there's a bit of an issue comparing something that is to the nearest microsecond with something to the nearest millisecond. However, based on any sane rounding method, the fact remains that according to your clock in the first example you received the message before Betfair timestamped it. This might be expected infrequently but probably not to the extent that your example suggests. I suspect your system clock is not synchronised with an appropriate source. I wonder if this might explain the original observation

text:
Like I said

> I agree that there's a bit of an issue comparing something that is to the nearest microsecond with something to the nearest millisecond
But in the example I highlighted, your micros are 484417, Betfair's are 485000. We don't know what they did to the micros to arrive at 485000. If they truncated then your timestamp is definitely ahead of them. If they rounded up any value for 484500 or higher, your timestamp is still ahead of them

elements.text: Like I said
I agree that there's a bit of an issue comparing something that is to the nearest microsecond with something to the nearest millisecond

But in the example I highlighted, your micros are 484417, Betfair's are 485000. We don't know what they did to the micros to arrive at 485000. If they truncated then your timestamp is definitely ahead of them. If they rounded up any value for 484500 or higher, your timestamp is still ahead of them
